Situation1: Your I04iend has misunderstood the tone of your text message and replied sounding hurt. You need to call them right now to explain.
Expectation2: Review and analyze case files thoroughly before hearings.
Situation2: An emergency motion for a temporary restraining order has just been filed, requiring you to immediately review the documents and make a ruling within the hour.
Story:
My phone buzzed with a message from Sam, my closest friend. His reply was curt, almost cold—he’d clearly misread the tone of my earlier text. I could feel the tension in his words, and my heart sank. I knew I needed to call him right away, to explain, to clear the air before the misunderstanding grew roots. That’s what friends do: we talk things out, we don’t let silence fester.

But just as I reached for my phone, my clerk rushed in, breathless. An emergency motion had landed on my desk—a request for a temporary restraining order. The law demanded my immediate attention. I had to review the case files, analyze every detail, and make a ruling within the hour. The weight of the court’s expectation pressed down on me; people’s safety could depend on my decision.

I stared at my phone, torn. My friend needed me, but so did my duty as a judge. The clock ticked louder, and I felt the two worlds pulling me apart, each demanding all of me, right now.
